ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was good overview into the director's relationship with the text, discussions of how to work with actors and tell a specific story.

This course does a great job giving you concrete skills in textwork. You will learn how to break down the mechanics of a play and of a scene in ways you can transfer readily into your personal projects.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was a great collaborative room with a lot of discussion amongst the small class and with Toni. I wish that certain assignments had been more specific in instruction. I particularly enjoyed bringing in the two scenes for both first-workings and revisions.

The exercises in this class can be somewhat general when it comes to purpose. If you're someone who, like me, needs to know why we're doing something, be prepared to be frustrated. Toni believes in learning by doing. Trust in her process: you will see results.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are interested in directing, and particularly with working closely with theatrical texts, this is the course for you.

Yes! Take this course! Toni is wonderful and readily tailors the work to fit your learning needs. Be warned, though: she's a stickler for deadlines. There's no flexibility when it comes to getting work done, unless you have a dean's excuse on hand.
